entry.title: Flood Advisory issued December 3 at 5:53AM AKST until December 4 at 7:45AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Record heavy rainfall on Sunday with moderate to heavy rainfall Monday and Tuesday has resulted in minor flooding in the Ward Lake recreational area.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Ward Lake near The Ward Lake Recreational Area.
* WHEN...Until 745 AM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas around Ward Lake.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 312 PM AKST Monday, the dam operator reported heavy rain in areas near the Ward Lake recreational area. Minor flooding is ongoing, especially near Ward Lake. Between 5 and 10 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches are possible Tuesday.
- For Lake Connell Dam: At 7:30am Monday the stage was 253.0 feet. Flood Stage is 252.0 feet.
Impacts: At 252.0 feet: 2 feet of water will be going over the emergency spillway which will produce minor flooding of areas around the Ward Lake recreation area with trails and Last Chance campground being inundated.

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 745 AM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued December 3 at 5:39AM AKST until December 3 at 9:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
After a brief break in rainfall overnight, heavy rainfall is returning Tuesday morning across the southern panhandle. The previous heavy rainfall has resulted in minor flooding near the Thorne River. The heavier rain will continue into Monday afternoon before diminishing Tuesday night.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Thorne River, especially near the Thorne River Bridge.
* WHEN...Until 900 PM AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 527 AM AKST, river gauge reports indicate rises in water levels from heavy rain in areas around the Thorne River bridge. Minor flooding is ongoing with the Thorne River currently near minor flood stage. Over 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible.
- For Thorne River near Thorne Bay: At 4:00pm the stage was 12.4 feet. Flood Stage is 12.5 feet.
Impacts: At 12.5 feet: Water will begin to flow over the road upstream from the Thorne River bridge.

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM AKST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Ice Storm Warning issued December 3 at 5:19AM AKST until December 3 at 3:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...FREEZING RAIN AND SNOW FOR THE NORTHERN PANHANDLE...
.Temperatures warming aloft with northwest surface winds below freezing will lead to widespread freezing rain for Haines and Mud Bay today. As aloft temperatures warm over the course of today, freezing rain is expected to expand northward along the Haines Highway. For the Klondike Highway, incoming moist conditions with with warm southerly flow will lead to increasingly wet accumulating snow up to 4 inches.
* WHAT...Significant icing. Additional snow accumulations of up to one inch and ice accumulations of around one quarter of an inch.
* WHERE...Haines and Haines Highway.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM AKST this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Greatest freezing rain accumulation expected around Haines and Mud Bay. As aloft temperatures warm during the day, expect freezing rain to expand up the Haines Highway.

cap:parameter.value: ICE STORM WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM AKST THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 3 at 9:07AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
At 907 AM EST, radar indicated an intense lake effect snow band over Geneva-On-The-Lake, moving southeast at 20 mph.
HAZARDS INCLUDE... Visibility rapidly dropping to less than a quarter of a mile...
Locations impacted include... Ashtabula, Conneaut, Geneva-On-The-Lake, Geneva, Madison, North Kingsville, Perry, Austinburg, Kingsville, Pierpont, North Perry, Edgewood, Plymouth Center, North Madison, and Kelloggsville.
Use extra caution if you must travel into or through this lake effect snow band. Rapid changes in visibility and potentially slick roads are likely to lead to accidents. Consider delaying travel until this snow band passes your location.

cap:parameter.value: An intense lake effect snow band will affect northeastern Lake and central Ashtabula Counties Until 1030 AM EST.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 3 at 4:19AM AKST until December 4 at 5:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation. Total ice accumulations of a glaze to one tenth of an inch and snow accumulations of up to 3 inches. North winds gusting 35 to 50 mph, strongest near the coast.
* WHERE...Bristol Bay.
* WHEN...Until 5 PM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Power outages are possible. Travel could be extremely hazardous.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Multiple rounds of light precipitation will bring continued chances for freezing rain through Wednesday afternoon. The highest likelihood for freezing rain and ice accumulation will occur along a line roughly from Dillingham north through Koliganek, in the area east of the Ahklun Mountains. Temperatures are expected to rise above freezing and switch precipitation to plain rain from east to west Wednesday afternoon as winds at the surface shift from northerly to southeasterly.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 3 at 4:19AM AKST until December 5 at 3:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation expected. Total snow accumulations of up to one inch and ice accumulations of around a trace. Winds gusting 20 to 40 mph, strongest near the coast.
* WHERE...Kuskokwim Delta.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM AKST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Multiple rounds of light precipitation moving from south to north will increase chances for freezing rain. Today's precipitation is expected to be hit and miss with light snow and freezing drizzle more likely near the Kuskokwim Mountains to about the Kuskokwim River. Additional moisture will move through the area beginning Wednesday morning, increasing the likelihood for freezing rain near the Kuskokwim Delta coast, especially south of the Kuskokwim River. Northerly winds along the Kuskokwim River will keep temperatures near the surface well below freezing resulting in a much lower chance for frozen precipitation through Thursday away from the coast. However, Bethel cannot be ruled out for at least a glaze of ice.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM AKST THURSDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 3 at 4:19AM AKST until December 5 at 3:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Cold air will keep precipitation through Thursday as mainly light snow across much of the area despite multiple rounds of light precipitation moving from south to north into the area. entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued December 3 at 7:05AM EST until December 3 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Lake Effect Snow Warning, heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations between 1 and 3 inches with up to 5 inches in the northeast portion of the county. For the Winter Storm Watch, heavy lake effect snow possible. Total snow accumulations in excess of 8 inches possible with locally higher amounts to 12 inches where snow bands persist. Winds could gust as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...Crawford County.
* WHEN...For the Lake Effect Snow Warning, until 7 PM EST this evening. For the Winter Storm Watch, from Wednesday afternoon through late Thursday night.
* IMPACTS...Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday morning, Wednesday evening, and Thursday morning and evening commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...An Arctic front will cross the region on Wednesday evening and could bring a band of heavier snow with quickly deteriorating conditions, including a quick inch or two of snow, visibility of 1/4 mile or less, and wind gusts to 45 mph. * WHERE...The Eastern Lake Ontario Region. The greatest accumulations will be across the higher terrain of the Tug Hill Plateau.
* WHEN...From Wednesday afternoon through late Thursday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Gusty winds could down tree branches and cause isolated power outages.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 10:36PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Since the transition from snow Monday morning, up to an inch of rain has fallen across the area.
Rain is expected to continue through Monday night followed by another round of heavy rain for Tuesday. 1 to 2 inches of rain is expected through Tuesday night.
Due to significant snow pack from the recent storm and frozen ground from recent cold temperatures, runoff will have a difficult time keeping up with this amount of rain. Expect ponding of water on roadways and for some creeks to spike up. Snow removal will become more difficult due to higher water content making the snow heavier. Boat owners should check on their vessels. Additionally, areas of compact snow will become very slippery.
Please let the National Weather Service office know if you are seeing impacts from this rainfall.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued December 2 at 7:50PM AKST until December 3 at 11:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Another round of heavy rain will move into the central and southern panhandle early Tuesday morning along with warming temperatures. This may expand localized flooding.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...The following areas, Prince of Wales and Southern Inner Channels. This includes the cities of Craig, Klawock, Hydaburg, Coffman Cove, Thorne Bay, Ketchikan, and Metlakatla.
* WHEN...From 1 AM AKST Tuesday through Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, other low-lying areas and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain. Flooding may occur in poor drainage areas.
Emergency Managers report that a small slide occurred sometime late Sunday night near Carlanna Creek in Ketchikan. Officials request that you immediately call in any unusual activity on hillsides.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Rainfall amounts over the southern panhandle Sunday through Monday afternoon have been 3 to 6 inches with localized amounts of around 10 inches in the Ketchikan area.
Heavy rain will move back into the region early Tuesday morning. New rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches with localized amounts of up to 4 inches are expected through Tuesday evening. Additionally, freezing levels will rise to above 8,000 feet Tuesday morning.
Strong wind gusts of around 45 mph are also likely during this timeframe.
- Storm drains should be kept clear of debris as much as possible.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Prince of Wales Island; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM 1 AM AKST TUESDAY THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued December 2 at 7:50PM AKST until December 3 at 11:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Another round of heavy rain will move into the central and southern panhandle early Tuesday morning along with warming temperatures. This may expand localized flooding.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt is possible.
* WHERE...The following areas, Southern Inner Channels and Central Inner Channels. This includes the cities of Gustavus, Juneau, Petersburg, Kake, Port Alexander, Wrangell, And Hyder.
* WHEN...From 1 AM AKST Tuesday through Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, other low-lying areas and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain. Flooding may occur in poor drainage areas.
Heavy rain falling on the existing snowpack will lead to increased runoff. Rain falling on the hard pack snow will lead to icy conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Rainfall amounts since the change over from snow have been 1 to 2 inches for Juneau, Gustavus, and Kake, upwards of 3 inches in Petersburg and Wrangell, and lesser amounts so far in Hyder.
Heavy rain will move back into the region through early Tuesday morning. New rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches expected through Tuesday evening. Additionally, freezing levels will rise to around 6,000 feet Tuesday afternoon.
- Storm drains should be kept clear of debris as much as possible.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; City of Hyder

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 3:08PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Over the last 36 hours, portions of the southern panhandle have seen significant rainfall accumulations of over 3 inches, ranging to around 9 inches in parts of Ketchikan.
After a short-lived lull in the rain Monday night, another round of heavy rain is expected for Tuesday. Rainfall totals through Tuesday are expected to be 1 to 3 inches, with up to 4 inches in Ketchikan and Annette Island.
Runoff will have a difficult time keeping up with this amount of rain, particularly in areas where the ground froze over the last week. Expect ponding of water on roadways and for flashy creeks to spike up. Boat owners should check on their vessels.
Additionally, each round of heavy rain will have strong winds with gusts greater than 40 mph likely.
Please let the National Weather Service office know if you are seeing impacts from this rainfall.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

entry.title: Air Stagnation Advisory issued December 2 at 3:55PM PST until December 4 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A ridge of high pressure will lead to a strong inversion and stagnant air conditions near the surface that will continue to trap pollutants. This could worsen air quality over time.
* WHERE...Valley locations across southern Oregon. West of the Cascades, this includes the Umpqua, Illinois, Applegate, and Rogue valleys. East of the Cascades, this includes Klamath Falls, Sprague River, Chiloquin, Chemult, Silver Lake, Paisley, and surrounding areas.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Poor air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems.
